Check the vocabulary list and definitions, click on the terms in boldÂ to practice listening to their pronunciation.Â ThisÂ way, when you listen to the podcast, you will be able to easily identify them!

In your portafolio, write down their pronunciation as you hear it.Â ðð¼

  1. Regarding: with respect to; concerning; about.
  2. Approach: mention; analyze; talk about.
  3. Obesity: the conditionÂ of beingÂ grosslyÂ fatÂ orÂ overweight.
  4. Loaded: informal expression that means âfull ofâ.
  5. Worldwide: extending or reaching throughout the world.
  6. Drive-through (drive-thru): a place or facility whereÂ oneÂ canÂ beÂ servedÂ withoutÂ leavingÂ one'sÂ car.
  7. Tends: toÂ regularlyÂ orÂ frequentlyÂ behave in a particular way or to have a certain characteristic.
  8. Morbidity: the rate of disease in a population.
  9. Mortality: death, speciallyÂ onÂ aÂ large scale.
  10. Raised: moreÂ intense than usual; higher.
  11. Doing a number on: informal way of saying toÂ treatÂ harshly; toÂ damage.
  12. Sides:Â aÂ foodÂ item that accompanies the entrÃ©e or main course at aÂ meal.
  13. Carbohydrates: one of severalÂ substances (such asÂ sugarÂ orÂ starch)Â thatÂ provideÂ theÂ bodyÂ withÂ energy;Â foodsÂ containingÂ theseÂ substancesÂ such asÂ bread,Â potatoes,Â pasta, andÂ rice.
  14. Fiber: theÂ partÂ ofÂ foodÂ that isÂ eatenÂ but notÂ digested, itÂ passesÂ through theÂ bodyÂ and isÂ excretedÂ asÂ waste.
  15. Cholesterol: aÂ substanceÂ containingÂ a lot ofÂ fatÂ that isÂ foundÂ in theÂ bodyÂ tissueÂ andÂ bloodÂ of allÂ animals, it isÂ thoughtÂ to beÂ partÂ of theÂ causeÂ ofÂ heartÂ diseaseÂ if there is too much of it.
  16. Weight gain: itÂ is an increase in bodyÂ weight. This can involve an increase in muscle mass, fat deposits, and excess fluids such as water or other factors.
  17. Insulin: aÂ hormoneÂ in theÂ bodyÂ thatÂ controlsÂ theÂ amountÂ ofÂ sugarÂ in theÂ blood.
  18. Type 2 diabetes: it is a problem with your body that causes blood glucose (sugar) levels to rise higher than normal. This is also called hyperglycemia.
  19. Asthma: aÂ medicalÂ conditionÂ that makesÂ breathingÂ difficultÂ byÂ causingÂ theÂ airÂ passagesÂ toÂ becomeÂ narrowÂ orÂ blocked.
  20. Shortness of breath: theÂ feelingÂ of not getting enoughÂ airÂ when you areÂ breathing.
  21. Pounds: aÂ unitÂ forÂ measuringÂ weight.
  22. Bone density: a measurement of the amount of calcium and other minerals in a segment ofÂ bone.
  23. Muscle mass: white tissue connected to the skeleton through tendons which generates corporal movement.
  24. To price: informal expression to give a value or worth to something.

University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

...Â andÂ answer in your notebook.

Which type of lifestyle do you follow? According to Duran, which are some consequences to eating junk food? Is eating healthy food during the semester difficult? Why or why not? What can be done to improve eating habits?Â
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
Check it
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
The information from the audio has been summarized in the paragraphs below. Complete the text with the corresponding words. You may listen to the audio again for help.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Veronica Duran celebrates her 10thÂ episode with a special topic regarding our eating choices: fast food vs health. She is a medicine student from the autonomous University of Zacatecas so she approaches this topic from the medical version.

The main idea of her discussion is to learn about the effects of fast food in our body and how it is related to health problems such as obesity and bad nutrition. In fact, as a result of bad nutrition, the rate of morbidity and mortality has raised.

Most fast food are loaded with carbohydrates with little to no fiber. This reflects on the elevation of bad cholesterol and glucose in the blood stream . This increases your risk for weight gain, insulin assistance, and type two diabetes . It also may lead to obesity.

Obesity can increase your risk for respiratory problems such as asthma and shortness of breath. The extra pounds also put pressure to your heart and lungs and it can also lead to complications with bone density and muscle mass. People who are obese have a greater risk for falling and breaking bones.Â 

In general, Duran believes itâs truly complicated to change your habits and choose a healthy lifestyle because it involves many things such as economy and personal will, but with double efforts and doing our best, we can reach better, healthier eating habits!
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

The main idea of her discussion is to learn about the effects of fast food in our body and how it is related to health problems such as obesity and bad nutrition. In fact, as a result of bad nutrition, the rate of morbidity and mortality has raised.

Most fast food are loaded with carbohydrates with little to no fiber. This reflects on the elevation of bad cholesterol and glucose in the blood stream . This increases your risk for weight gain, insulin assistance, and type two diabetes . It also may lead to obesity.

Obesity can increase your risk for respiratory problems such as asthma and shortness of breath. The extra pounds also put pressure to your heart and lungs and it can also lead to complications with bone density and muscle mass. People who are obese have a greater risk for falling and breaking bones.Â 

In general, Duran believes itâs truly complicated to change your habits and choose a healthy lifestyle because it involves many things such as economy and personal will, but with double efforts and doing our best, we can reach better, healthier eating habits!

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.
Type the question stem. The question should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.
